awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: The Role of Neutral Winds in the Day-to-day Variability of the Ionospheric Mid-Latitude Evening Anomalies
awd_abstract_narration:
The Weddell Sea Anomaly (WSA) is a recurrent feature of the Southern hemisphere summertime midlatitude to high-latitude ionosphere. Electron densities maximize around the Weddell Sea region during the night, rather than during the day as would be expected due to photoionization by the Sun. The objective of the work is to understand the causes of these evening anomalies, with particular attention to the roles of thermospheric neutral winds, and waves originating from the lower atmosphere. Because winds are not directly sensed in this part of the atmosphere, they must be inferred from other available measurements such as electron density. A key value of the research is the generation and dissemination of observation-driven global-scale ionospheric winds computed from the PI's state of the art model.

The WSA can be thought of as testbed for coupled ionosphere/thermosphere modeling capabilities. The primary research tool is USU's Thermospheric Wind Assimilation Model (TWAM) that will be coupled to an ionospheric assimilation system (GAIM). These two systems ingest data from a comprehensive set of ground-based  and space-based data networks. They will enable investigation of the wind response to day-to-day variations in ionospheric drivers inside and outside the anomaly regions. This proposal is very well-aligned with the goals of the most recent Decadal Survey, which charges the thermospheric modeling and data assimilation communities with providing winds in data-absent regions.

por.por_cntn:
Neutral winds in the Earth upper atmosphere play an important role in the transport of momentum and energy in the upper atmosphere and affect the composition, dynamics and morphology of the ionized part of the upper atmosphere. Although the general morphology of the winds is well understood, we are only starting to understand it?s variability. During the last decade it has become inherently clear that the lower atmosphere is an important driver of the variability seen above, which can, for example, be due to direct propagation of waves from the lower atmosphere into the upper atmosphere, secondary waves generated on the way, or internal feedback mechanisms between the neutral and ionized parts of the upper atmosphere. Therefore, an understanding of variability in the Earth?s upper atmosphere and its causes is critical for an improved understanding of this region.

We have used ground- and space-based observations of the neutral wind and of the ionized particles in the upper atmosphere together with a data assimilation model that is similar to the ones used for the daily weather forecast to investigate the variability in this region.

Our investigation revealed that variability in the neutral winds was significantly correlated across different latitudinal, longitudinal, and temporal regimes and we identified clear longitudinal variations in the global zonal wind that generally resembled each other from year to year. We found that the longitudinal variation of the zonal wind during dusk exhibited a change in the global patter from 2010 to 2011, but closely resembled each other during the years 2009/2010 and 2011/2012, respectively. From year-to-year a clear progression was identified in individual wave structures that contributed to the observed variability. We found that month-to-month variations in the neutral winds derived from our data assimilation model were in good agreement with those seen in ground-based observations of the neutral winds at various locations around the globe. This result indicates that data assimilation models are a valuable tool to investigate the global winds in the Earth?s upper atmosphere.

The results of the project have been disseminated at both national and international conferences and workshops and publications are in progress. A significant part of the project was performed by a female Hispanic graduate student helping to improve the involvement of female scientists in STEM research.
